job_title: High School Admissions Representative in College Station, TX
pros: Helping the people into a career instead of another job
cons: They way the company is ran

review_title: The bad out weighed the good toward the end.
pros: You  get an opportunity to foster some great relationships with other employees in the admissions department. Meeting students and watching those that apply themselves transition into career professionals.
cons: None of the departments work together. If you look up the definition of hostile work environment, after 2 months, you will see all the characteristics at the Beaumont campus. The only way that you will be able to last at this campus within the admissions department is if you truly care about the students. Eventually, that won't be enough. I was actually told from a manager that "this was a war". ( during another conflict with another department) I thought, "no this is not a war, I fought in a war during my military enlistment. And I shouldn't have to return and war to do a job I was paid to do! This is a highly stressful job that never lets up. The vacation and PTO is almost comical if it wasn't a reality.

job_title: Military Admission Representative in El Paso, TX
pros: Working at Vista was a great chance to help military affiliated students and prospects pursue a new career or change of career.  I think the college itself is great and I would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a new start or a change of career.  As a Military Representative, I had a little more leave way than regular Rep's with my work/life balance
cons: Working at Vista College can have it's ups and downs.  You are constantly threatened with being fired if you don't enroll a certain amount of students at the beginning of each school start and it can get ugly between admission reps because of the high stress.  Training for outside Rep's such as Military, High School, and Special Admissions is not the same as with regular Rep's because the Director for those teams are not on-site to administer it properly.  So, sometimes those Reps are thrown in with the crowd and have to fend for themselves.  Lastly, depending on the workload, work-life balance can be unpredictable.

pros:
1. Great hours
2. The people are fantastic.
3. You may be treated to lunch at times.
cons:
1. Over indulging the students
2. Inconsistent policies
3. Lack of communication between departments
4. Lack of staff or personnel development and training: FERPA and compliance trainings do not count. 
5. Since there is a start every month, there is hardly any time to regroup, reflect, and revise processes. Too many changes are made on the fly which isn't the best way at times. Which leads to...
6. Occasionally overwhelming and stressful with hardly any moment to get caught up.
7. Disorganization and lack of structure
8. Benefits are mediocre.

review_title: A company that you can grow with!
job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Las Cruces, NM
pros: That I was able to grow within the company. When I first started working here, I started off as a receptionist. They allowed me to show them my working potential and promoted me. I appreciate that they want their current employees to climb to the top with leadership classes and opportunities. To me that is a great quality for a company to have.  Their slogan is true to what they stand for, "We create opportunities." and for me they did just that.
cons: I really do not have cons, work can be hard but in a good way. You have to give your all for this company when it comes to long days, but it is worth it in the end.

review_title: Only those willing to bend the rules make it
job_title: Anonymous Employee in El Paso, TX
pros: The pay is good in some departments, some of the staff is actually nice people. We got lunches often. Not too many good things I can say sadly.
cons: If you don't bend the rules they way they do, they will replace you with someone that will. The obvious favorites are on top. Brown nosing is key. Incompetent people in manager roles. The school stands for a big lie. Don't care for quality, prefer quantity. They do anything to keep students and cash in on them.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Las Cruces, NM
pros: Getting to work with students that actually want to be there is a plus.
cons: For being a for-profit school, the computers are not current, they are slow, not upgraded and low quality. The equipment necessary to teach is not always prioritized in the classrooms.

job_title: Program Director in College Station, TX
pros:
Excellent place to work at! Excellent place to study at!
Great opportunity for people to make a difference in their life with a second chance to gain education and make a career.
All education institutions have some short comings and challenges but Vista owns it's responsibility.
Vista finds the best available instructors and willing to pay higher than other institutions just to provide better educational experience.
All the Directors go out of their way to help students.
cons: None that any other educational institution would not have.

pros: You really get to help these students change their lives, and you can leave every day feeling like you've made a difference.
cons: Unless you are in the Admissions department, you will feel invisible. They are treated to lunches and constantly praised for barely meeting expectations. The other departments are typically ignored by management (even at the corporate level) to the point that most feel unhappy day-to-day. There is talk of being a team but the only teamwork is within individual departments.

review_title: As far as predatory career colleges go, this one is really cares about their students.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Station, TX
pros: The company excels at taking care of their students and keeping them in school. The HVAC department including the program director is outstanding, as are the Medical Billing & Coding instructors.
cons: Long hours; Abrupt changes in company policy to meet accreditation compliance without adequate guidance from corporate; Lack of communication between departments; Backstabbing; Inefficient and incompetent campus director. Condescending and patronizing attitude of some staff towards students. High staff turnover rate. The campus is relatively new and is undergoing growing pains.

job_title: Director of Education in Fort Smith, AR
pros: Vista College is a smaller educational institution which focuses on the well-being of the students, employees and community.  The are many opportunities for growth and love that each campus has it's own personality, but we all share in a common mission.  Great team atmosphere.
cons: The long hours can sometimes wear on you, but at the end of the day it's worth it.

pros: The wonderful student that are hungry to learn. Ability to guide students to a new career and see them succeed. A lot of really great instructors and staff.
cons: campus leadership shows little concern for students and faculty needs. Unqualified people in leadership positions. IT program director has no real-world experience and a degree in marketing. WOW! Student and staff concerns and complaints are swept under the rug or ignored. If you don't drink the Kool-aid you get fired. Leadership is driven by money and students suffer for it.

pros: I get to teach without a whole lot of politics.
cons: Some instructors, including myself, have a split shift schedule: 8:30 a.m. - 1:00 p.m., 5:30 p.m. - 10:00 p.m. The upside to this is working M - Th. But some Friday mornings are required for staff meetings. Most instructors are hired on as adjunct (contract) without benefits.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor Medical Assistant in El Paso, TX
pros: They are a very student friendly social circle. The groups teach social and community involvement.
cons: There is a great Circle of preferred instructors that are given a lot of clout , and if you do not meet their personal criteria, you are shunned. The gossip runs rampant and to ignore it only causes you to be thrown into the web. It is hard to stay focused and impartial.

pros: The company has come a long way since I started with them.  They are doing their best to grow and be visionaries in a challenging market.
cons: Clear communication is tough.  Campuses tend to deviate from policies because they think it is better for them.  They are just now learning that people are more important then $$$

pros: Upper Management, supporting futures of students
